title: Synthetic Recap
body:
CLEVELAND – On a night where the basket seemed as wide as Lake Erie for everyone else, it was a suffocating defensive masterpiece that sealed a gritty playoff victory. The Cleveland Cavaliers, powered not by an offensive explosion but by a historic defensive effort, ground out an 85-78 win over the Indiana Pacers.

The story of this Eastern Conference battle was written not on the scoreboard, but in the stat sheet’s steals column. Cleveland’s Terrell Brandon authored a performance for the ages, single-handedly dismantling the Pacers’ offensive flow. The All-Star point guard was a phantom in the passing lanes, a pickpocket in open space, recording a staggering **10 steals**. This wasn't just a career-high; it was a defensive clinic that demoralized Indiana at every turn.

Each of Brandon’s ten thefts snuffed out a Pacers possession and fueled the Cavaliers’ transition game. While no Cavalier reached 20 points, Brandon’s 17 points, combined with his game-high 8 assists, were more than enough. Every time Indiana threatened to build momentum, Brandon’s hands would appear, a critical deflection or a clean strip swinging the energy back to a raucous Cleveland Arena.

The Pacers, led by Reggie Miller’s 22 points, simply had no answer for the relentless pressure. Their 78-point total stands as a testament to the defensive stranglehold Cleveland, and specifically Terrell Brandon, imposed. In a low-scoring, physical playoff war, one man’s historic defensive genius made all the difference, proving that championship-caliber wins are built on more than just scoring.
